comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Broomfields, ship chandlers and hardware merchants (see note), was trading as John Broomfield Ltd. until at least 14 October 1920 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16870435. Became Broomfields Ltd. by 10 November 1921 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15979697 Twenty four pigs being driven along Day Street, Sydney, by a truck, ca. 1929 by Sam Hood So, we have our start date: 1920/21 or after ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: John Keep and Sons Ltd., hardware merchants (see note), amalgamated with Holdsworth, Macpherson, and Co., Ltd. on Monday 31 October 1927 to become Keep, Macpherson, Ltd. They moved from 104-108 Sussex Street to 252 George Street. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16403530 & trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28054908. The merger, however, wasn't a success, owing to the Depression, and the historic company proposed voluntary liquidation in 1931 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16751069. Which gives us an end date: 1920-1927. Unless, of course, they didn't remove their painted sign from the building right away? ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good start!

Can anyone decipher the ship's name?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Aha! It looks like they are filling in Darling Harbour.  Get out your magnifying glasses and look at the large size of this wonderful "c.1927" map,  which has marked a "PROPOSED ROAD" between Pyrmont and Bathurst Street.  South of that, in small print is "Under reclaimation Gillespie Bros & Co. by AUSS[?] & Co's Wharf <u>Railway Department</u>", which might explain the provenance of this photo via the State Railway Authority Archives 17420 Series.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6662642331/sizes/o/in/photostream/]

So I vote for c.1927.
